Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID--Smoke Forecasting Support for the Western Wildfire Experiment for Cloud Chemistry, Aerosol absorption and Nitrogen (WE-CAN) Field Intensive
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is providing forecasting capabilities for the NSF-sponsored Western wildfire Experiment for Cloud chemistry, Aerosol absorption and Nitrogen (WE-CAN) field campaign. WE-CAN is a major field intensive planned for summer 2018 and includes deployment of sophisticated atmospheric chemistry instrumentation on the NSF/NCAR C-130 to sample and systematically characterize the emissions and first day of evolution of western U.S. wildfire plumes. Planning for this field campaign is currently underway and forecasting capabilities are urgently needed to ensure the success of the campaign. The WE-CAN field campaign will provide new information about emissions from wildfires, including information on the emissions of major toxic species in smoke plumes, the evolution of fine particulate matter in the plume over time, and the interactions of smoke particles with nearby clouds.

The support for WE-CAN provided by this effort includes the use of (1) the real-time High Resolution Rapid Refresh smoke (HRRR-Smoke) modeling system, and (2) the FxCAVE (Forecast-extended Common AWIPS Visualization Environment) virtual client that delivers operational National Weather Service (NWS) forecast observations and forecast models. There will be at least 4 graduate student forecasters involved in WE-CAN.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this collaborative project was to provide forecasting support to the WE-CAN field campaign in summer 2018. We set up and simulated the High-Resolution Rapid Refresh model coupled with Smoke (HRRR-Smoke) for the contiguous US (CONUS) domain on 3km spatial resolution. Four times a day a new HRRR-Smoke simulation started to forecast smoke (particulate matter emitted by wildland fires) for next 36 hours. The fire radiative power (an indicator for heat flux generated by a fire) data from multiple polar orbiting satellites were used to estimate the biomass burning emissions, which were subsequently ingested by the model in real time. The high spatial resolution of the model grid enabled simulating the meteorology over complex terrain in the western US, where typically large wildfires occur during summer.

In addition to the HRRR model, another model Rapid Refresh coupled with Smoke (RAP-Smoke) was set up and running for this project during summer 2018. The RAP-Smoke domain (13km spatial gridding) covers the entire North America, Hawaii and parts of South America and western Europe. The intensive wildfires in the western Canada contributed significantly to some of the smoke events in the northwestern US during summer 2018. The transport of smoke from Canada to the US was captured by the RAP-Smoke model, which subsequently provided boundary conditions to the HRRR-Smoke model. RAP-Smoke also forecasted smoke four times a day for next 48 hours.

The RAP- and HRRR-Smoke models produced large sets of the forecast data of weather (e.g. temperature and wind), surface visibility, biomass burning emissions and the distribution of smoke concentrations in the air. The smoke concentrations were displayed on horizontal (near surface and at 1000ft and 6000ft above ground) and vertical cross-section plots (catalog), which were provided to the users via a public web-page: https://rapidrefresh.noaa.gov/hrrr/HRRRsmoke/

In addition, we provided the KML files to visualize the HRRR-Smoke forecasts on Google Earth, so they can be utilized in the flight planning. The model forecasts helped the researchers to plan the aircraft flight trajectories for sampling of smoke plumes from different wildfires burning in the western US. The CO-PI Ahmadov participated in the flight planning discussions and coordinated the smoke forecast product development with the WE-CAN team throughout the campaign.
